questions.text: A 1-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department 25 minutes after having a seizure. His mother reports that he has become lethargic and does not cry as vigorously anymore. Examination shows muscular hypotonia and hepatomegaly. Arterial blood gas on room air shows metabolic acidosis. Serum studies show elevated levels of methylmalonic acid. A deficiency of which of the following types of enzymes is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Dehydrogenase enzymes catalyze redox reactions. Common diseases of dehydrogenases include maple syrup urine disease (branched-chain α-ketoacid dehydrogenase), pyruvate dehydrogenase complex deficiency, lactate dehydrogenase deficiency, and medium chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency. Dehydrogenases are not involved in methylmalonyl-CoA conversion.

B) INCORRECT:

Phosphorylase enzymes are crucial to several carbohydrate metabolic pathways where they aid in glycogenolysis by adding inorganic phosphate groups onto their substrates. When deficient (e.g., McArdle disease, Hers disease), affected patients may present with muscle weakness, hypoglycemia, exercise intolerance, hepatomegaly (as seen in this patient), or rhabdomyolysis. However, serum studies will not show any evidence of methylmalonic acidemia as phosphorylase enzymes do not participate in the conversion of methylmalonyl-CoA to succinyl-CoA.

C) INCORRECT:

Methionine synthase deficiency will present with elevated serum levels of homocysteine (absent in this patient) and methylmalonyl-CoA. A cystathionine synthase deficiency will also result in homocystinuria and affected patients will be clinically similar to patients with a methionine synthase deficiency. Affected patients may present with myopia, ectopia lentis, intellectual disability, skeletal anomalies (resembling Marfan syndrome), and thromboembolic events, none of which are seen in this patient. This patient's presentation and serum analysis are more indicative of a different enzyme deficiency that causes methylmalonic acidemia.

D) INCORRECT:

Carboxylase enzymes transfer carbon dioxide groups and require biotin as a cofactor. Notable examples include pyruvate carboxylase (carbohydrate metabolism), acetyl-CoA carboxylase (fatty acid synthesis), and propionyl-CoA carboxylase (odd-chain fatty acid degradation). Although deficiency of enzymes of this type can lead to organic acidemias, they are not involved in the conversion of methylmalonyl-CoA to succinyl-CoA.

E) INCORRECT:

Hydroxylase enzymes add a hydroxyl group (−OH) to their substrate. In the liver, the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase (PAH) converts phenylalanine to tyrosine. A defect in PAH is the hallmark of phenylketonuria (PKU). Affected patients may present with seizures, as seen in this patient. However, eczema, psychomotor retardation, blue eyes, and light pale hair are more characteristic of PKU. Hydroxylases do not participate in the conversion of methylmalonyl-CoA to succinyl-CoA.

F) CORRECT:

Methylmalonyl-CoA mutase is the enzyme that catalyzes the isomerization of methylmalonyl-CoA to succinyl-CoA. A deficiency of methylmalonyl-CoA mutase, or its cofactor vitamin B12, will result in accumulation of methylmalonic acid in the serum. Methylmalonic acidemia in neonates typically presents with lethargy, vomiting, dehydration, failure to thrive, hepatomegaly, hypotonia, and encephalopathy. Affected patients are at risk of severe morbidity if disease is left untreated.
questions.hint: Elevated levels of methylmalonic acid in the presence of metabolic acidosis are suggestive of methylmalonic acidemia, which is most commonly caused by a deficiency of an enzyme that catalyzes the conversion of methylmalonyl-CoA to succinyl-CoA.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her grandfather because of confusion and agitation that began 2 hours after she ingested an unknown plant in the family's garden. Her temperature is 39°C (102.2°F) and pulse is 110/min. Examination shows warm and erythematous skin and dilated pupils bilaterally. Based on these findings, the physician administers an antidote, which alters the activity of an enzyme. Plots depicting the inverse of the enzyme's in vitro initial reaction velocity [1/V] as a function of the concentration of the enzyme's endogenous substrate [1/S] before and after administration of the antidote are shown. Which of the following best describes the effect of the antidote on the enzyme?

choices.text: Antidote binds irreversibly to the enzyme's active site and inhibits enzyme activity
Antidote binds to the enzyme's allosteric site and promotes enzyme activity
Antidote binds reversibly at the enzyme's active site and inhibits enzyme activity
Antidote binds to a site other than the enzyme's active site and inhibits enzyme activity
Antidote binds reversibly only to the enzyme-substrate complex and inhibits enzyme activity

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Inhibition of enzyme activity as a result of a drug irreversibly binding to the enzyme's active site (competitive irreversible inhibition) would cause a decrease in Vmax and no change in Km, unlike the findings seen on this Lineweaver-Burk plot. Organophosphates and sarin are examples of irreversible competitive inhibitors of the enzyme that is being altered by the drug administered to this patient; the drug itself, however, alters the enzyme's activity in a different way.

B) INCORRECT:

Promotion of enzyme activity as a result of a drug binding to the enzyme's allosteric site is called positive allosteric modulation (PAM), which would typically cause a decrease in Km without a significant change in Vmax, unlike the changes seen here. Moreover, in PAM, the Lineweaver-Burk (LB) plot would be a curve rather than the straight line seen here because positive allosteric modulators exhibit positive cooperativity and follow Hill kinetics rather than Michaelis-Menten kinetics; LB plots are, therefore, not useful for determining Km in allosteric modulation.

C) CORRECT:

Inhibition of enzyme activity as a result of a drug reversibly binding to the enzyme's active site is called reversible competitive inhibition. In this type of nonallosteric enzyme inhibition, an increase in the substrate concentration can overcome the binding of the drug to the enzyme's active site. Therefore, Vmax, which represents the theoretically possible maximum reaction rate if the substrate concentration was infinite, remains unchanged and the Michaelis-Menten constant (Km), which is the substrate concentration at which half of Vmax is achieved, increases, as seen here.

This patient with confusion, agitation, tachycardia, fever, cutaneous vasodilation, and mydriasis most likely has anticholinergic toxicity because of the ingestion of Atropa belladonna. Anticholinergic toxicity is treated with physostigmine, a competitive, reversible inhibitor of acetylcholinesterase that crosses the blood-brain barrier.
Image Description:

Regarding the Michaelis-Menten kinetics, the most important parameters of an enzyme reaction are shown in the Lineweaver-Burk diagram: the y-axis represents the reciprocal of the reaction speed, whereas the x-axis represents the reciprocal of the substrate concentration. The reciprocal of vmax can be taken directly from the intersection point of the straight and the y-axis, whereas the reciprocal of KM (with negative sign) can be taken from the intersection point of the straight and the x-axis. Both values can as well be identified by the slope of the line, as the slope is calculated by the quotient of KM and vmax.

D) INCORRECT:

Inhibition of enzyme activity as a result of a drug binding to a site other than the enzyme's active site is called noncompetitive inhibition, which would result in a decrease in Vmax without a change in Km, unlike the findings seen on this Lineweaver-Burk plot.

E) INCORRECT:

Inhibition of enzyme activity as a result of a drug binding only to the enzyme-substrate complex (uncompetitive inhibition) causes a decrease in both Km and Vmax, unlike the findings seen on this Lineweaver-Burk (LB) plot. In uncompetitive inhibition, the LB plots of enzyme activity before and after the addition of the drug would be parallel lines, not nonparallel lines like the ones seen here.
questions.hint: The plot of the reciprocal of the enzyme's initial reaction velocity against the reciprocal of the substrate concentration is called a Lineweaver-Burk plot (LB plot). The LB plot of an enzyme following Michaelis-Menten kinetics is a straight line with a y-intercept that is the maximum reaction velocity's reciprocal (1/Vmax) and an x-intercept that is the negative of the Michaelis-Menten constant's reciprocal (-1/Km). In this case, the LB plot after the addition of the antidote indicates that Vmax remains unchanged (because the y-intercept remains unchanged) and Km increases (because the absolute value of the x-intercept decreases).

questions.text:
A group of investigators discovers a novel monomeric enzyme that cleaves glutamate-valine bonds in a bacterial exotoxin. The substrate binding site of the enzyme is rich in aspartate. A sample of the enzyme is added to two serum samples containing the bacterial exotoxin. One sample is assigned a test condition while the other is maintained as the control. The averaged results of several trials comparing Vmax and Km between control serum and test serum are shown.



Vmax (μmol/min)
Km  (mM)



Control serum
13.2
81.2


Test serum
28.8
80.9



Which of the following conditions in the test serum would best explain these findings?

choices.text: Presence of a noncompetitive enzyme inhibitor
Presence of a reversible competitive inhibitor
Presence of an irreversible competitive inhibitor

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Serum power of hydrogen (pH) is the negative logarithmic scale of hydrogen ion concentration of the serum (pH = -log[H+]). Both the aspartate-rich binding site of the enzyme and the glutamate-valine cleavage site on the bacterial endotoxin have low isoelectric points. An increase in pH (assuming optimal pH in the control) would increase the net negative charge in both molecules, increasing the force of electrostatic repulsion, leading to a decrease in substrate binding and an increase in the Km. In this case, the Km in both the control and test samples remained almost the same.

B) CORRECT:

An increase in enzyme concentration increases the total number of active sites available to catalyze a reaction. It is the only method of increasing the maximum rate of reactions for an enzyme (Vmax) that has the unit of concentration/time. The Michaelis constant (Km) is the concentration of substrate at which the enzymatic rate is Vmax/2. Therefore, an increase in enzyme concentration does not change the Km of the enzyme. Km only changes with changes in affinity to the enzyme.
Image Description:

This diagram illustrates the reaction velocity (v) of a certain enzymatic reaction in relation to its substrate concentration ([S]) in an otherwise stable environment. It yields a solubility curve with an initial steep rise with subsequent plateauing (hyperbolic solubility curve).

The maximum reaction velocity (Vmax) is indicated by the plateau phase which is achieved at maximum substrate concentrations. KM is defined as the substrate concentration at which the reaction velocity equals 50% of Vmax. Generally speaking, Michaelis-Menten kinetics demonstrate that the reaction velocity of an enzymatic reaction with steady enzyme concentrations is primarily dependent on substrate concentrations. This means, that low substrate availability results in a decreased likelihood of a successful enzymatic reaction since diffusion off the enzyme diminishes reaction velocity. However, a surplus of substrate results in negligible diffusion that allows the enzyme to work at maximum speed. Further increase of substrate concentrations would fail to increase reaction velocity since all enzymes are already saturated.

C) INCORRECT:

The exotoxin, in this case, is the substrate. Adding more substrate has no effect on Vmax or Km, as these are properties intrinsic to the enzyme.

D) INCORRECT:

Noncompetitive inhibitors bind to sites on enzymes other than the active site. These inhibitors do not compete with the formation of substrate-enzyme complexes and therefore do not change the Km. Rather, these inhibitors lower the efficacy of enzymes by allosterically altering the active site. Therefore, it would be expected to see a decrease in Vmax and no change in Km, which was not the case here.

E) INCORRECT:

Reversible competitive inhibitors bind to enzyme active sites, physically blocking enzyme-substrate complex formation. It takes a greater concentration of substrate to displace the competitive inhibitors, thereby increasing the Km, while the Vmax of the enzyme would stay the same. These results are opposite to what was seen in the experiment, where the Vmax increased and the Km remained the same.

F) INCORRECT:

An irreversible competitive inhibitor binds to the active sites of enzymes, preventing the formation of enzyme-substrate complexes. As the binding is irreversible, no increase of substrate concentration would displace the inhibitor, meaning the Km would remain the same as long as the concentration of the inhibitor is not as high as the enzyme concentration. Meanwhile, the total number of functional enzymes would be reduced, decreasing the Vmax. These results are opposite to what was seen in the experiment.
questions.hint: The Michaelis constant (Km) is the substrate concentration at which the velocity of the reaction is half of the maximum reaction velocity (Vmax). In this study, Vmax is increased in the test serum while the Km remains nearly the same.
